ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We had live seminar discussions and professor had office hours.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think my French writing improved a lot, as well as my ability to think and speak on my feet.
Improved my French vocabulary and speaking/reading and writing skills.

We memorized a bunch of French vocabulary and went through some French literature and films, and French-speaking picks up as the class is discussion-based. I think the course helps you memorize vocabulary, revise some grammar, and start to develop speaking skills.

My speaking and writing skills in French improved tremendously! Further, I gained the ability to discuss complicated topics, such as immigration and sexism, in French. I was also introduced to new grammar topics, and I gained mastery over old ones.
French speaking, comprehension, writing and grammar

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: In a year where most classes did not have a lot of engagement, this class was a welcome change, as the way in which it was set up provided for a lot of engagement.
Enjoyed how the course was in the form of a discussion and how we would use our time in class to discuss material we had worked on at home. Sometimes the amount of homework was a little too much.

Strength: Professor Helverson was great! She was quite nice and responded to emails and gave us office hours when needed. The discussion based learning was great. 
Weakness: The curriculum might be revised so that there is more in-depth development of different skills for certain students. I feel that Fren150 is when students really start picking up skills in some areas of French (while other areas are still difficult), and it's different for each person. I think that some way to individually keep track and check in regularly with a professor would be great. The professor prepared us for the material on the exam, but the exams themselves were difficult.

A strength of the course is the class size. The small class ensures that everyone participates, therefore we were all able to improve our speaking skills. Another strength was how intensive the class was: the homework & our projects really allowed us to engage with all the concepts we had learned.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The breakout rooms were very good as they allowed for more discussions or everyone. I think generally that this course just lent itself well to being virtual because it was a smaller class size and could therefore still allow everyone to stay engaged.
I enjoyed how engaged the Professor and students were with one another despite COVID-19. Nonetheless, our class had under 10 people so I almost wish that it was safely organized in-person.
Zoom discussions and office hours were good.
The breakout rooms and small group activities worked well virtually. The fact that our teacher consistently called on us ensured that we all got to engage with the material.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes. I thought it was very helpful in terms of progressing in the French language, and ti was also just a fun course.
Yes. If a student learning French is looking to largely deepen their knowledge and french language skills then this course will be both interesting and helpful for them.
Yes! If you did alright in French courses before or plan on taking more French, this is a great course, especially with Professor Helverson.
I would absolutely recommend this course. For every student who wants to improve their French language skills.
